issue.body: This PR makes MinGW, one of windows compiler, be able to compile the ginkgo library (shared/static). It is part of #281 The requirement is git, mingw(64bit), and WSL. WSL is used to run the bash to update the header automatically. 1. gflags library's name is gflags_nothreads_static.lib in WINDOWS 2. std::this_thread::sleep_for does not sleep for the duration of nanosecond. [reference](https://github.com/gabime/spdlog/issues/609) The implementation depends on the compiler/system. the clock uses system_clock not steady_clock Now, use `Sleep(millisecond)` in `windows.h` for testings. Moreover, change the clock of `stop/time` according to #293. The picture in the end shows `sleep_for` doesn't work as we expect. 3. `update_ginkgo_header.sh` can handle `\r` in Windows. 4. Windows creates two files for one shared library, one is for compile and the other is for runtime. But windows does not have rpath for runtime library searching. I add the output in the end of cmake about the settings. Users need to add them manually for run the program. sleep_for 1 ms might only sleep 0.5 ms.

issue.title: Replace `std::this_thread::sleep_for`
issue.body:
We're doing a lot of short sleeps to wait for some async operation to finish or to see if a pipe was created in the meantime. However, particularly on Windows, this seems to introduce absurdly large overheads where it seems like sleeping very shortly ends up as sleeping for a very long time instead.

Maybe using a condition variable's `wait_for` is the better approach, even if that requires using a Mutex...

Ref.: https://stackoverflow.com/q/51817018/3907364
